Course information
The PhD is a supervised program designed to allow you to conceptualise and implement a major research project on a topic of personal interest. The course comprises of a major research project (thesis) of not more than 80,000 words with no coursework component.
All students of the Monash Doctoral Program with Education also need to complete 120 hours of Graduate Research Professional Development training over the duration of the degree.
The key research areas in the Faculty of Education include:
Curriculum and pedagogy Early years Educational psychology and inclusive education Maths, science and technology Teacher education, language, arts and professional learning Globalization, leadership and policy
Entry requirements
Admission criteria for the Doctor of Philosophy requires one of the following minimum qualifications in a relevant discipline:
a four-year bachelor's degree which normally includes a research component in the fourth year, leading to honours 1 or 2A; or a coursework master's degree with a significant research component including at least 25% of one full-time equivalent year of work, including a thesis (Please note that it is normally expected that a grade of honours 2A has been obtained for the research thesis or project); or a qualification which the Graduate Research Committee has deemed equivalent.
Applicants must also meet the university English language requirements.
Course fees
Domestic: The Australian government covers the tuition fees for all domestic PhD students. You will be required to pay an annual Student Services and Amenities Fee (SSAF).
International: Please note that fees are subject to change annually. The international student fee for 2016 is $29,900 per full-time year.
Scholarships opportunities are available.
How to apply
The PhD application process involves six steps, outlined on the How to apply web page.
First, you need to decide on a research area. An Education research degree can be completed in any field of research where sufficient expertise and resources are available.
While deciding on a topic, you can browse our seven departments to see which is most related to your area of interest.
Next, you will need to find a supervisor who agrees to direct you in your research degree. You can browse for potential supervisors by topic or by name. When you email potential supervisors, please include a brief outline of your academic interests or project and a resume. You can refer to the Writing a research proposal page for guidance.
Once you have identified a supervisor, you will lodge an Expression of Interest (EOI) form. Please allow four weeks after sending in your EOI for an outcome.
If approved, you will be sent an invitation to formally apply.
Further information
For more details about research with the Faculty of Education, I encourage you to view the Education graduate research pamphlet and browse the 2016 Handbook entry for full course requirements.
